title: New property laws in Victoria are proposed to stop renters from being ripped off
text:
Dodgy landlords will be exposed in a public blacklist and will be have to be more transparent about rent under new laws designed to protect tenants.

The Victorian Government will propose a raft of new measures in July 2020 to increase transparency between landlord and tenant relationships.

Landlords will have to tell the tenant if they intend to sell the property and advertise a fixed rent cost to avoid overcharging, allowing occupants to feel more secure.

Dodgy landlords will be exposed in a public blacklist and will be have to be more transparent about rent to avoid tenants being ripped off under new laws

The tenant-friendly proposed laws would also ban landlords from imposing longer leases and changes the frequency of how often they change rent prices.

Blanket bans on pets in rental properties would be lifted as well.

Senior manager of rent at realestate.com.au, Jarrod Scott, said the proposed reforms 'are deigned to introduce greater honesty, accuracy and trust between tenants and landlords'.

Tenants will have to be notified if there is asbestos on the property - information which did not previously have to be revealed by landlords.

They will also have to inform the occupants if they plan to make modifications on the home, even minor ones.

The proposed reforms will also see an end to rental bidding, where tenants voluntarily pay more to increase their chances of staying on the property.

Landlords will have to tell the tenant if they intend to sell the property and advertise a fixed rent cost to avoid overcharging, allowing occupants to feel more secure

The blacklist will name agents and landlords who have breached their Residential Tenancy Act, allowing tenants to choose properties with more ease.

In Western Australia, the Make Renting Fair alliance is fighting to make at least 10 changes to how tenancies are regulated.

Some of the changes they are hoping to fight against are an end to unfair evictions and stabilising rent increases - just like Victoria has proposed.
